title: 112_hr4342
content:
The "Waterways Are Vital for the Economy, Energy, Efficiency, and Environment Act of 2012" or the "WAVE4 Act" recognizes the importance of the inland waterways navigation system for the nation's economy, energy reliability, efficiency in transportation of bulk commodities, and environmental protection. The purposes of the Act are to improve program and project management for navigation projects on inland waterways, optimize system reliability, minimize project completion schedules, eliminate delays, and prioritize investments for maximum benefits and reduced risk. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

Qualifying project means a construction or major rehabilitation project for navigation infrastructure of inland and intracoastal waterways authorized before, on, or after the date of enactment of this Act, not completed on the date of enactment, and funded at least in part from the Inland Waterways Trust Fund. Major rehabilitation project refers to a project for the restoration of a major project or feature with an estimated cost exceeding $100,000,000. The Secretary of the Army, through the Chief of Engineers, must mandate formal project management training and certification for project managers, assign only fully certified personnel as project managers, require risk-based cost estimation with 80% confidence level, and conduct independent external peer review for qualifying projects meeting specific criteria. The Chief of Engineers may designate projects for unique approaches, interagency interest, or at the request of a State Governor. Additionally, the Inland Waterways Users Board member must be included in project teams, receive quarterly updates on construction progress, and contribute to project management plans. Lessons learned from past projects must be continuously applied. The Chief of Engineers may designate projects for unique approaches, interagency interest, or at the request of a State Governor. Additionally, the Inland Waterways Users Board member must be included in project teams, receive quarterly updates on construction progress, and contribute to project management plans. Establishment of a system to identify and apply lessons learned from prior projects to improve on-time and on-budget completion. Evaluation of early contractor involvement acquisition procedures for better project delivery performance. Implementation of additional measures determined by the Secretary to achieve the Act's purposes. The Chief of Engineers may designate projects for unique approaches, interagency interest, or at the request of a State Governor. Inland Waterways Users Board member must be included in project teams, receive updates on construction progress, and contribute to project management plans. Establishment of a system to identify and apply lessons learned from prior projects to improve completion. Evaluation of early contractor involvement acquisition procedures for better project delivery performance. Implementation of measures to achieve the Act's purposes, including development of standard designs for inland navigation locks, use of full-funding contracts, and establishment of procedures for recommending new project construction starts using a capital projects business model. SEC. 6. 20-YEAR CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM. The Secretary of the Army, in collaboration with the Inland Waterways Users Board, must present a 20-year program for capital investments on waterways to Congress within a year of this Act's enactment. This program should be updated annually, detailing any changes to project recommendations and national project-selection criteria. The Secretary of the Army, with the Inland Waterways Users Board, must review and update the capital investment program for the Inland Marine Transportation System every 5 years, making necessary revisions and submitting a strategic review to Congress. SEC. 7. COST SHARING FOR QUALIFYING PROJECTS. One-half of the construction cost of a qualifying project is funded from the general fund of the Treasury, and the other half from the Inland Waterways Trust Fund. Dams are an exception and are funded solely from the general fund. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON EXPENDITURES FROM THE INLAND WATERWAYS TRUST FUND. Section 9506 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit expenditures from the Inland Waterways Trust Fund. This includes restrictions on using funds for dam construction or rehabilitation projects under $100,000,000. Additionally, the Trust Fund cannot cover costs exceeding the authorized amount for Federal projects. The amendment to Section 9506 of the Internal Revenue Code limits expenditures from the Inland Waterways Trust Fund for Federal projects. The total cost cannot exceed the authorized amount specified in the project's authorization law, adjusted for inflation, and any additional amount agreed upon by the Secretary and the Inland Waterways Users Board. The Inland Waterways Trust Fund financing rate is amended to 26 cents per gallon after 2012, as per Section 4042(b)(2)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
